video.title: Maths for Programmers Tutorial - Full Course on Sets and Logic
video.description:
Learn the maths and logic concepts that are important for programmers to understand.

Shawn Grooms explains the following concepts:

⌨️ (00:00) Tips For Learning
⌨️ (01:32) What Is Discrete Mathematics?
⌨️ (03:45) Sets - What Is A Set?
⌨️ (06:22) Sets - Interval Notation & Common Sets
⌨️ (08:25) Sets - What Is A Rational Number?
⌨️ (10:18) Sets - Here Is A Non-Rational Number
⌨️ (12:17) Sets - Set Operators
⌨️ (13:45) Sets - Set Operators (Examples)
⌨️ (15:49) Sets - Subsets & Supersets
⌨️ (17:30) Sets - The Universe & Complements
⌨️ (20:02) Sets - Subsets & Supersets (Examples)
⌨️ (21:56) Sets - The Universe & Complements (Examples)
⌨️ (24:16) Sets - Idempotent & Identity Laws
⌨️ (25:14) Sets - Complement & Involution Laws
⌨️ (27:08) Sets - Associative & Commutative Laws
⌨️ (28:42) Sets - Distributive Law (Diagrams)
⌨️ (30:22) Sets - Distributive Law Proof (Case 1)
⌨️ (32:07) Sets - Distributive Law Proof (Case 2)
⌨️ (33:48) Sets - Distributive Law (Examples)
⌨️ (35:25) Sets - DeMorgan’s Law
⌨️ (37:32) Sets - DeMorgan’s Law (Examples)
⌨️ (39:38) Logic - What Is Logic?
⌨️ (41:26) Logic - Propositions
⌨️ (43:06) Logic - Composite Propositions
⌨️ (44:41) Logic - Truth Tables
⌨️ (46:30) Logic - Idempotent & Identity Laws
⌨️ (48:13) Logic - Complement & Involution Laws
⌨️ (49:58) Logic - Commutative Laws
⌨️ (51:35) Logic - Associative & Distributive Laws
⌨️ (53:09) Logic - DeMorgan’s Laws
⌨️ (54:23) Logic - Conditional Statements
⌨️ (55:45) Logic - Logical Quantifiers
⌨️ (57:59) Logic - What Are Tautologies?

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

-মোল্লা উমরের তালিবান (১৯৯৬-২০০১) ইসলামিক তালিবান। আর 2020 and later তালিবান Jewish Taliban। 
$#%

-শ্রীলঙ্কার (2022) অর্থনৈতিক সঙ্কট→সম্ভবত এই সঙ্কট ইহুদীদের  (UN, ইউরোপিও ইউনিওন, China, রাশিয়া, USA, বিশ্বব্যাঙ্ক, IMF- কে ব্যাবহার করে) তৈরী,-যেন, শ্রীলঙ্কার সংখ্যাগরিশঠ বউধ্ব জনগন ভারতকে ঘ্রিণা করার বদলে   ভালবাসে আর আস্তে আস্তে ভারতের নেত্রিত্বকে মেনে নেয়। আর ভারতও শ্রীলঙ্কার অর্থনৈতিক সঙ্কটে সাহায্যের হাত বাড়িয়ে দিয়েছে।

(3)1917 সালে সমাজতন্ত্র প্রতিষ্ঠা কারীদের (karl Marxএর দাদা ইহুদী,বাবা খৃষ্টান/ Leninএর দাদা ইহুদিথেকে 1824 সালে  খৃষ্টান,লেনিন এর নানা ইহুদী/ ত্রতস্কি সহ),More than 80% from ইহুদী বংশের।

4:57 Note: A set is not an array (JavaScript also has a Set data structure.) Sets follow the "axiom of extension." Order and duplication do not matter. For example, the following sets are considered equal:
{1, 2, 3 } = { 3, 3, 1, 2, 2, 1}

topLevelComment.author: David James
topLevelComment.text:
46:42 - P XOR P = not P (if P is true), so you said apply a binary logic operator and get back the same value as the original (P in this case).  Seems like an error in your statement to me.  Also, the sentence construction is wrong.  "If you recall, idempotence is...".  That is the wrong use of an if statement.  Idempotence is not what it is as a result of us recalling what it is.  For example, if someone didn't recall what it is, idempotence is still the exact same thing.  Our recollection or not of it has nothing to do with what it actually is. A XOR B is true if exactly one of A,B is true but NOT both, so if P is true, P XOR P is false.  It is not clear if you meant can apply ANY binary operator or SOME binary operator for idempotence.

Here is another example of a misuse of the word if...  if you drink milk, you will die.  This is generally false because many people have been known to drink milk and not die as a result of it.  This statement is however true:  All people that drink milk will die.  This is because the drinking of milk is not directly linked with the death of that person.  Since all people eventually die, we can substitute just about anything such as all people that take vitamin supplements will die.  Also a true statement.  If you tell a cop "You will die", you haven't said anything incorrect, but I wouldn't recommend it.

topLevelComment.author: Arthur Clifford
topLevelComment.text: While I appreciate this series of videos and agree that you have simplified a subject fairly well, it doesn't feel like it is for programmers. If it was you would be showing && || == === !=  and logic operators and showing how bits flip when you do perform those operators in a language like javascript with examples on jsfiddle so that people can try things in their browser and see how things change. If you are going to tell a would be programmer about a set, you should be talking about arrays (or bits in a byte) as the programmer's equivalent of sets and how logic operations can be done with them. If a programmer hasn't learned about arrays they aren't a programmer. If you speak math at a rookie developer you are not speaking their language. This is math(s) for math(s). Most sets a programmer are going to deal with are strings, arrays of data, or doing database queries. SQL would be a far better visual application of what you are talking about so you could show how a query can do unions or doing a relational query and show the notions of left inner and outer joins, or right inner or outer joins, and show what you get when you do them. Introducing a bunch of syntax that exists on no keyboards helps nobody.

topLevelComment.author: Marcus Anderson
topLevelComment.text:
Oh dear.  @9:10 the fake "0.999... = 1"  equality hoax again, and in a treatment of Set Theory no less !!!.   NO IT DOESNT.    You omitted the least significant 9 in the second step making the third step false:
        THIS IS WRONG -->  10x - x  =  9x = 9    <---WRONG
Try This ... 

10x = 9.999...9
    x = 0.999...99         <---DID YOU NOTICE THE EXTRA "9" ????
10x - x = 8.999...91    <---RIGHT
       9x = 8.999...91     <---RIGHT
so     x = 0.999...99    <---RIGHT

THIS IS WHERE THE FALLACY LIES - replacing "... "with an infinite (or UNDEFINED) number of 999'does NOT mean you can just go right ahead and omit the least significant digit after dividing x by 10 in the 2nd step. Calculation involving the convention of recurrence notation is UNDEFINED because it involves infinity which literally means UNDEFINED, but if you are going to go ahead and DEFINE infinity anyway by calculating with it, at least be consistent and don't omit the least significant 9.

IT IS BY CONVENTION ONLY that the recurrence function "...: when applied to recurring 9 is rounded up to the next integer, but its NOT an equality. THIS IS PARTICULARLY THE CASE IN SET THEORY.  

Stop spreading fake maths.

topLevelComment.author: David Nitzsche-Bell
topLevelComment.text:
Non-rational numbers section. You're trying to prove that sqrt(2) is irrational, but you glossed over/skipped/delayed some key points. First, it's easier if you assume that a and b are co-prime (they share no common factors besides 1) which means that a/b is irreducible. This needs to be stated as an assumption a the beginning, not thrown in in the middle/end.

It feels like your proof that "a is even" is back to front. I'd start with "let a = 2k" (a is even). "a squared" is therefore "4 times k squared" which is obviously also even. Starting with "a squared = 2 times (2 times k squared)" is a big leap to make, since this video is ostensibly for people who are wary about math.

In general, for this section, I'd start out with something like. "We just discussed rational numbers. What about irrational numbers? Irrational numbers are ones that..... <fill in here>, such as the square root of 2. How do we know that the square root of 2 is irrational? Well, let's first assume it's *rational* and see what we get..... 

I just think your explanation could be improved.

replies.author: David Kizivat
replies.text: The topics discussed in the video are basically just foundations for you to be able view your programming assignments (be it at work or school) in precise, rigorous "language" (math), which with (a bit, or rather a lot of) training will significantly help you to think about the problems and come up with better solutions to them easier. It's a bit shame this video doesn't follow up on the set theory with relations and functions, but those would be topics that build on top of the covered portion and would usually follow it in college classes. With that theory, for example, you could view the "subroutines" (aka "functions" or "methods" etc.) as a mathematical function with some domain co codomain and if you can define what those are and what is roughly is the expected output, you can often easily connect (reduce) your problem to some well known and researched math problem which would lead you to correct solution (again, thanks to training) without much hustle.

replies.author: David Kizivat
replies.text: it's hard to explain without a Venn diagram (look that up for some visuals), but here is a try: The meaning of a "symmetric difference of sets" is basically "all elements of A that are not in B, together with (symmetrically) all elements of B that are not in A". Symmetric, because you take out common elements from both sets, instead of just one in the case of basic set difference A \ B, or B \ A. So going by the said meaning: "all elements of A that are not in B..." part is just A \ B, the symmetric part is B \ A, and to put the resulting elements together in one set, we unify the results => (A \ B) ∪ (B \ A).

topLevelComment.author: Siddharth Panjwani
topLevelComment.text:
There is a mistake here at 10:43. If you are assuming that b^2 is a separate integer then a^2 is not equal to 2 times b^2. 
For it to be equal, a^2 should be equal to (2b)^2 which is not the same. 

For example:
(4)^2 = (2x2)^2 = 16.

As per the assumption in this video,
(4)^2 = 2 x 2^2 where
(4)^2 = 16
2 x 2^2 = 8
16 is not equal to 8
Therefore the assumption to prove a^2 is even is wrong and b^2 cannot be taken separately.

replies.author: weelkeen
replies.text:
In the first column: both sides are squared, then multiplied by b^2
Then, since a^2 and hence a are even, a should be = 2 * k 
=> a * a = 2 * k * 2 * k 
or, a^2 = 2 (2 * k^2)
In the second column: knowing that
2 * b^2 = a^2 = 2 (2 * k^2)
=> 2 * b^2 = 2 * (2 * k^2)

The topics in this video are just foundation for you to be able to use math as language to describe problems and solutions.
